title: five-epic-munros-adventure-seeking-scots-attempt
story: With breath-taking views at the top, theres no wonder why adventure-seekers take to the climb for hours on end.But with almost  to pick from, it can be a dficult decision.Here, weve pulled together five Munros wed love to try:Braeriach, CairngormsThe Cairngorms are quite dferent to many of other Scottish mountain ranges. Although their summits are mostly rounded and sweeping, they combine to make a vast and wholly unique landscape.The mountains in the Cairngorms rise up out of the remnants of the ancient Caledonian pinewoods and are home to superb wildle and an array of dramatic corries. Braeriach is the third highest mountain in the British Isles and is protected by a long approach walk through a natural tree line.This Munro comes in at km and takes around - hours to complete.Braeriach, Aviemore, PH QTBraeriachBeinn Alligin, TorridonBeinn Alligin, meaning jewelled mountain, is one of three of the Torridon giants and well deserving of its name. This magnicent pair of munros has its own pinnacle ridge called the Horns of Alligin.Sitting on the seaward side of Torridon it has an unmatched viewpoint with glimpses of Skye and the sea to one side, and great peaks on the other side with the Horns providing a stunning foreground.The Munro is around km and takes around - hours.Beinn Alligin Torridon, Alligin, AchnasheenBuachaille Etive Mor, Glen CoeBuachaille Etive Mor is the head of Glen Coe and reigns supreme with its awe-inspiring pyramidal appearance. It is affectionately known by many climbers as the Bookie and, along with its twin Buachaille Etive Beag, are among the most photographed of the Scottish mountains and itrsquos easy to see why!This Munro is perfect for those who want a climb and some incredible views.It is around km and takes around - hours to complete.Aonach Eagach Ridge, A, Ballachulish PH HXLiathach, TorridonAnother of Torridonrsquos three mountains, Liathach is perhaps the finest of them all. Its higher Munro looks almost inaccessible from most directions and even the easiest ascent involves a bit of scrambling but itrsquos certainly worth the effort.Beyond this point the mountain becomes even more dramatic and offers the perfect path for thrill seekers to climb to the top. The hidden north side of the mountain is even more spectacular and is well worth exploring.Slightly longer than the other of Torridonrsquos mountains this walk is around .km and takes around - hours.Achnasheen, IV ETLiathachSgurr nan Gillean, SkyeMany regard Sgurr nan Gillean as being the finest peak on Skye and it is one of the more dficult on this list. Even the easiest ascent on the southeast ridge is a pretty tough scramble ndash the other two ridges venturing into the realm of rock climbing.It appears fairly dramatic from Sligachan but this actually conceals much of the mountainrsquos finest features and its only upon a closer visit to Coire a Bhasteir that the true scale and magnicence of the Pinnacle Ridge reveals this Munrorsquos true stature.This walk is around km and takes roughly  to  hours to complete.Skye, IV SW

title: angelina-jolie-interviewed-schoolgirl-bbc-newsround
story: Sofia Roper, an S student at North Berwick High School, was offered the opportunity to talk with the actress, and her -year-old co-star Brooklynn Prince, by BBC Newsround.Sofia, , said: ldquoIt was fun but it was also scary. It was overwhelming.The budding journalist was hired by the BBC after the news channel approached the schoolrsquos humanities department, asking to interview students about their highs and lows of lockdown.The Newsround crew were so impressed by the video submitted by Sofia that they offered her the chance to become a reporter and interview, via an online video call, the stars of new film The One And Only Ivan.Sofia, of High Street, East Linton, told the Courier that she did some research before talking to the film star.She said: ldquoI chose to do some research because itrsquos good to have a personal aspect to your questions.ldquoI practised interviewing with Ali Plumb [BBC Radio  film reporter] and it was much easier, I didnrsquot feel nervous at all talking to him, but then when I talked to Angelina I was very nervous. And I donrsquot understand why!Sofia joined  professional journalists on video conferencing  Zoom, all waiting for their slot to interview the Hollywood stars.Student Sofia Roper waits on Zoom to interview Angelina JolieShe said: ldquoIt was hard to hide that I was so nervous and imagine that I was talking to a completely normal person.ldquoAngelina and Brooklynn were friendly but they made me feel very scared, just because they had this kind of presence you could tell they were more confident.But Sofia said the experience had also made her more confident and was one she would be happy to have again.She said: ldquoOne of my old teachers was saying that I was a lot more confident now than I was when she taught me.Sofiarsquos proud mum, Soledad Garcia Ferrari, said: ldquoIt was all very unexpected. Shersquos been brilliant. She had to do lots of videos in preparation, she had to watch the film and comment on it.ldquoIt was so funny seeing all the little windows on Zoom, of all the reporters from all over the world.ldquoAnd the interview was two hours later than planned, so she was sitting by her computer for two hours waiting.ldquoBut Angelina was very friendly.Georgina Brownlee, one of Sofiarsquos teachers in the humanities department, said: ldquoThe BBC got in touch during lockdown to ask for some clips of pupil lsquolockdown highs and lowsrsquo and a number of our junior pupils participated by entering a personal -second video clip, broadcast on Newsround during lockdown.ldquoFrom there, the BBC editor got in touch to ask Sofia to do a further interview, this time on the new Disney film The One and Only Ivan, starring Angelina Jolie.ldquoThe humanities faculty are delighted with Sofiarsquos impressive performance during her inaugural role as a BBC reporter she did a superb job interviewing a Hollywood megastar.ldquoSofia is a dedicated student and we will continue to facilitate the links and opportunities that have emerged from the BBC for all of our pupils.As for Sofiarsquos next journalist experience  The junior reporter said shersquod like to chat with a YouTuber.She said: ldquoI like YouTubers because they donrsquot have a script.ldquoYou donrsquot have to interview them to know what kind of person they are. Theyrsquore funny and entertaining.ldquoI like Georgia Productions ndash shersquos my favourite.The interview is at bbc newsround

title: coronavirus-maskne-seven-ways-look-skin-wearing-masks
story: However, people wearing face coverings every day have been noticing that they have started to break out in acne, rashes and skin irritations.Have you had more breakouts since you started wearing a mask We have spoken to Dermalogica skin care expert and beautician Ashley Richards to find out why this happens and how you can protect your skin.What is ldquomaskne Maskne occurs when sweat, oil and bacteria are trapped on your skin while wearing a mask, creating the perfect breeding ground for breakouts.What causes it Maskne is caused by friction, rubbing, and occlusion of the skin by outside forces.Wearing a mask can trap dirt, oil, swear and humidity around the skin.Friction and irritation from the mask pushes bacteria into the skin, which creates micro-tears, and allows the bacteria and dirt to enter the skin more easily.This will lead to blackheads and whiteheads along the bridge of your nose, cheeks and chin. Masks can trigger ious types of skin irritationsand redness .There isnrsquot a prevention for maskne, as we need to continue wearing our masks, but there are ways that you can help combat the issues.Skin Care routineIf you want to combat the impact of maskne then having a good skincare routine is essential.It is just as important to cleanse your skin before wearing a mask as it is to cleanse after wearing a mask.To help your skin heal, Ashley would recommend using a squalane or balm cleanser so help remove make-up, dirt and debris.However,you are experiencing chapped, irritated skin or suffer from sensitivity then a gel based cleanseradvised.Dermalogicarsquos UltraCalming Cleanser helps to calm and cool sensitised irritated skin.ExfoliatingExfoliating is key to clear clogged pores and remove dead skin cells which will help reduce the impact of maskne.There are thousands of dferent types of exfoliators available from chemical, physical and masks but it is always important to follow the recommended application and how often you should use the product.Over-exfoliating your skin can compromise your skins barrier , damage the skins capillaries and dehydrate the skin.Ingredients such as glycolic acid, lactic acid and salicylic acid are great exfoliating athelping fight breakouts.Spot treatmentsUsing targeted spot treatments with ingredients such as salicylic acid and benzoyl peroxide will help remove dead skin cells and decongest pores.Hyaluronic AcidsHyaluronic acid can hold , times its weight in water - so it is like a magnet for moisture.Using hyaluronic acid regularly will leave the skin feeling super-soft, radiant and reduce the appearance of fine lines and wrinkles.Hyaluronic acid has antibacterial properties meaning it will help soothe and protect chapped, irritated skin.FoundationsOpt for tinted moisturisers rather than a heavy foundation or go bare faced to help cause less clogging in your pores - but donrsquot forget your SPF!MoisturisersHeavier moisturisers will sit on the skin for longer due to the humidity of wearing the mask which can cause further clogging and irritation of the skin.However, donrsquot want to stop using a moisturiser all together as our skin still requires hydration and moisture.Instead try using a light and soothing moisturise such as Charlotte Tilburyrsquos Magic Cream light.Chapped SkinFor those suffering from chapped skin try using a physical barrier cream such as Dermalogicarsquos Barrier Repair.Barrier Repair shields against environmental pollution and helps forty sensitive skin with a damaged barrier.

title: musselburgh-man-kevin-yip-admonished-breaching-asbo
story: Kevin Yip was ordered not to have more than two visitors to his home at Newbigging when the ASBO was imposed on him at Edinburgh Sherf Court in May .The order was handed out following several complaints of noise and anti-social behaviour from Yip and visitors to the property.But the -year-old broke the order on February  this year when police officers found he had more than two people inside the flat.Yip appeared at the Capital court last Tuesday, where Sherf John Cook heard he had not been in any more trouble since and he was admonished on the complaint.Not guilty pleas to allegations of possession of diazepam and behaving aggressively towards police officers on the same date were accepted by the Crown.

title: housing-plan-musselburgh-poundland-poundstretcher-post-office-site
story: An outline plan has been drawn up for the land and building that houses Poundstretcher, Poundland and the Post Office, which is currently up for sale.Edinburgh-based Scarlett Land and Development is inviting offers for the ldquoprime location with ldquoconsiderable redevelopment potential on behalf of the owner, who has not been named.Situated on the corner of Dalrymple Loan and High Street, an outline plan for  residential properties plus two commercial units has been drawn up for the site, subject to planning permission.Scarlett Land and Development stated: ldquoThe site lies in the defined town centre, adjacent to the Musselburgh Conservation Area and in close proximity to listed buildings.ldquoPlanning permission will be required for any redevelopment proposal and, whilst not allocated for any specic use within the East Lothian Local Development Plan, it is likely that a mixed use development of ground floor commercial with residential use above will be acceptable, subject to a high-quality scheme respecting the setting of the listed buildings, the character and appearance of the adjacent conservation area and the scale of buildings in the surrounding area.Architects have drawn up an outline scheme comprising of  residential units plus two commercial units at ground level fronting High Street. The housing is listed as one, two and three-bedroom properties, plus two commercial units of  and  sq.m.A spokesperson for Poundland said: ldquoWe rent the store from the landlord and so the ownership is not really our concern. But we love being in Musselburgh and are proud to be part of the townrsquos retail community.A Post Office spokesperson said: ldquoThe premises where Musselburgh Post Office is based are up for sale. Poundstretcher is the company that operates this Post Office. We have not received any resignation at this stage, so it is business as usual at this Post Office.Poundstretcher had not responded at the time of going to press.Colin Beattie, Musselburgh MSP, said: ldquolsquoAny business being put up for sale comes at a cost to the community, as with the loss of a local business comes a loss of jobs and services to the area.ldquoWhile we come out of the Covid- pandemic, we need businesses as we start to re-energise our economy. Though we also need more houses to be built locally, I would hope that these are not replacing valuable businesses locally ndash a decision which is permanent and negatively affects the lives of anyone employed there.ldquoI hope that suitable thought goes into this proposal and that the iniduals that this would affect are given the utmost consideration.ldquoAs always, I hope that the highest attention is given to the views of those who live in the community, as their opinions are what really matter in planning decisions.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothian MP, said: ldquoDevelopment is needed but must be appropriate for a busy location and central site.Musselburgh Conservation Society said it would reserve its position until members saw what was being proposed.Musselburgh resident and Green campaigner Jason Rose, via social media, mooted the idea of the community owning the site and asked members of the public what they would like to see.One post stated: ldquoA proper covered market with independent fishmongers, grocers and butchers, plus other local producers and space for outdoor stalls too.ldquoWhat is needed is parking. No parking, limited shoppers, added a member of the public.Another said: ldquoSomething for the creative industry would be good. Small units at reasonable rents, photography studio with workshop space, sound recording studio, rehearsal spaces for bands musicians.One post added: ldquoCould be nice to have a proper supermarket right on High St again.ldquoMy granny was forever complaining that Tesco was too far and it is quite a walk.

title: tims-tales-learning-outdoors-can-gift
story: In May, as I was sitting in my garden early one beautul morning, I actually heard a flock of swts above me. It was the sound of their wings that caught my attention before I saw them. It was a lockdown morning, no traffic, no background sound, and they were flying low.I never have been much of a bird watcher well, what I mean is I have always loved sightings of wildle, including birds, but donrsquot sit for hours to spot dferent types. I know the names of some birds but many I canrsquot identy with certainty. My friend Jim is my human encyclopaedia for such things.Of course, we can still appreciate nature and wildle without being able to identy their exact names. A beautul tree is still worthy of admiration, evenyou donrsquot knowitrsquos an oak or a sycamore. You can enjoy the antics of a flock of birds, evenyoursquore not surethey are martins or swts.And there are some wild creatures we all know and can identy: a fox, a robin, a hedgehog, a squirrel, a rabbit, a mole, a deer, a dandelion, a daisy, a heron, a swan, a duck and a hare would be on this list, but itrsquos not as extensive as it used to be. As nature has receded from our lived experiences, so has the ability to identy and name much of the wildle and plants that survive around us.The beautully illustrated book The Lost Words by Jackie Morris and Robert MacFarlane was a response to this loss of nature vocabulary. With beautul pictures and poems, it brings back to le some of the animals and flora of our land. And resources like the ranger service do a fantastic job in our county, providing walks, giving fascinating information and talking to a iety of groups.But itrsquos the lived experience of nature that is the vital link between having knowledge and developing an understanding that will nurture a love of our natural environment. We cannot really love that which we do not experience and value personally. Itrsquos when we physically encounter a plant or animal that we develop a desire to know its name and understand its signicance.This seems a perfect time to find ways to enhance that lived experience of nature. In schools, because of the presence of Covid, learning outdoors as much as possible is being promoted. Some schools will have access to woodland or natural areas more than others. Some schools in built-up areas will be more restricted. But even in urban areas, there may be a grassy area with a tree or two, or perhaps a nature corner can be created.Teachers do a great job, and they are doing so in very challenging circumstances just now they know their business. But as a storyteller who until the lockdown was in schools every week telling stories, I am unable to do so in these new circumstances. I fully understand why, of course.But as things develop, it may be possible for storytelling to take place outdoors, wersquoll see. For me this is not so much a restriction but a new opportunity to make nature the stage, with listeners immersed in the natural surroundings in which so many stories are set. Evenonly concrete playground is currently available, there is potential to make more of the outdoor space now that it will be used in a dferent way.As I say, time will tell what will be possible. My interest is not just as a storyteller but also as a parent. Itrsquos a time to be cautious and safe, yes, but let us not forget the vital importance of the creative arts in all this. Many children have missed out on so much already, and music, song, storytelling and drama are such a vital part of childrenrsquos development and soul indeed for us all. Perhaps we all need to relearn the campfire spirit, around which so much human culture and understanding developed.And so my thoughtsto the swts which flew over my garden. They will now be flying over Africa, following the rains and chasing the insects there. Their story is utterly fascinating a lesson in natural and human history, as well as geography, biology and ecology.Soon the pink-footed geese from Iceland will arrive in their honking formations, to spend their winter here. Irsquove noticed some trees are showing they already feel the nip of autumn. The cycle of naturersquos stories are all around us,we have an ear to listen and eye to notice.More learning outdoors is a gt. Letrsquos make the most of it.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-august-25-28-1995-1970-1920
story: A POTENTIALLY fatal craze in Dunbar was highlighted in the East Lothian Courier on August , .Children as young as  are risking their lives by ing ft into Dunbar harbour.The fine summer weather has enticed groups of youngsters to put on their swimming trunks and leap into the water at the harbour entrance.And warnings that their antics could be fatal have only moved the boys on to even more dangerous jumps into the rocky sea near the ruined castle.Dunbar community policeman PC David Munro said that the craze had been going on for several weeks and the dozen-strong group ldquodid not seem to appreciate the dangers.ldquoApart from the diesel, oil and other chemicals that are floating on the surface, the kids are also at risk from the boats that are coming in and out, he said.ldquoThey could easily fall on to rocks belowthey slipped or lost their footing and it is also worrying that younger children are coming along and want to imitate the older ones.A NEW school opened in Haddington, reported The Haddingtonshire Courier of August , .Haddingtonrsquos new school ndash Kingrsquos Meadow Primary School ndash opened its doors to pupils for the first time on Monday.The school, which cost about pound, to build, can accommodate  pupils.Built by James Harrison and CoLtd., Edinburgh, it was designed by Mr Colin Stewart, a Haddington man employed as an architect by the firm. He also supervised the building work.Kingrsquos Meadow is designed on modern lines. It has four basic teaching units, each comprising four classrooms and toilets, which are linked together by corridors.The headmaster of Kingrsquos Meadow is Mr R. C. Murdie, who has been employed by the local education authority for the past seven years.A FISHERMANrsquoS tragic death at Port Seton Harbour was reported in The Haddingtonshire Courier of August , .On Wednesday, about  a.m., while preparing to go to his boat which lay off the middle pier at Port Seton harbour, Mr John Harkess fell into the water.He was immediately noticed and, within a very few minutes, was brought to the cement slope on which the fish sales are held.An attempt was made to resuscitate Harkess, who was a man of about  years of age, but unsuccessfully.Medical aid was quickly forthcoming. Dr Ross, however, stated le was extinct, death being due to shock.

title: dave-berry-column-gosford-house-magnificent-secret
story: Lennoxlove is a modied peel tower Winton has architectural echoes of a fortication. But none has the Italianate opulence of Gosford.Behind two miles of high walls, Grade lsquoArsquo magnicence is hidden from public view.The estate the wall encloses was held by many Scots names before, being bought by the Wedderburns of Inveresk. They enclosed fields and laid out avenues of trees, evident on Royrsquos map of .In , it all passed to the seventh Earl of Wemyss, who had already added Amisfield, Morham and Abbey Mill to his extensive Fe estates.He gave the brilliant Robert Adam his last great commission, replacing an existing house. The surrounding parkland was redesigned by James Ramsey. Not completed until , both earl and successors disliked the result. Not only did they not move in, but the eighth earl even demolished both wings.In , the th earl commissioned replacement wings from William Young to house his collection of Italian and Dutch masters. Finally, in , the family moved in.The neoclassical result blends with Adamrsquos original concept and ranks among Scotlandrsquos grandest stately homes. The south wing became the family residence, with the entrance relocated here. A three-storey-high marble entrance hall carries two sweeping staircases up to the spacious gallery on the first floor.Following the th earlrsquos death in , the house was used as a hotel until being requisitioned by the army in , to be used as an officersrsquo mess for a large camp in the park.Unfortunately, the central block burned during a social event and suffered temporary roofing for years until the th earl, moved in in , provided a proper re-roofing in . He also refurbished the extensive ponds and permitted the first public tours, still limited to a half-dozen days around Easter and in August.The th earl was very active in civic le, holding many senior appointments in Scotland, including Lord Lieutenant for East Lothian and chairman and then president of the National Trust for Scotland between  and . He lived a long le to age , whereupon the titles passed to the present th earl. Despite remaining the family seat, the th earlrsquos business interests and those of his second we means they live in Gloucestershire and the house is again unoccupied ndash as was the case for over half its existence.

title: iain-gray-msp-column-rediscover-solidarity-lockdown
story: However, recess never actually happened ndash Parliament has continued to meet throughout the summer to deal with Covid- and related issues.It is a moment to pause and reflect, though. Over the summer, we have seen lockdown partially eased but that is not proving easy.Cases are rising again. The Government has had to slow down its lsquoroute maprsquo to opening society up, and that has led to what seem like contradictions.Pubs and restaurants open, but gyms and swimming pools closed young adults wearing face coverings in supermarkets but not in schools a list of lsquoquarantinersquo countries which changes almost daily.If this is the lsquonew normalrsquo, then in some ways it is proving harder than everyone being locked down. We all applauded the NHS as it coped so well with the virus peak, but many constituents are becoming frustrated at how long it is taking to open up for their routine treatments or operations.Only weeks ago we were hailing Scotland as doing so much better than England.It turns out the pandemic numbers were just being counted dferently, and local lockdowns around Manchester were followed by Annan and Aberdeen. Scottish people have proven just as likely to flock to the beach or ill-advised house parties as anyone .Everyonersquos patience is being tested now. We can do this, though. Remember the community spirit which saw resilience groups form in all of our towns and villages  Remember clapping for the NHS and social care workers  Remember looking out for vulnerable neighbours and friends  It is time to rediscover that solidarity and keep on looking out for, and looking after, each other.

title: merryhatton-gardening-column-five-great-evergreen-plants
story: Whilst itrsquos relatively easy to have lots of plants to enjoy in your summer garden, it is more dficult ndash but not impossible ndash to find plants that maintain interest during the remainder of the year.This month, wersquore highlighting five of our favourite evergreen plants that grow successfully in East Lothian and explaining the role that they can play in making your garden appealing all year round.Escallonia is top of our list because of its hardiness and tolerance to strong and salty winds, making it an ideal shrub for a coastal or hilltop location.With glossy green leaves and attractive flowers that last most of the summer, it is a medium-sized shrub reaching an ultimate height of .-. metres.It is frequently used as a hedge, forming a delightful windbreak for some of the less robust plants.Depending on the iety chosen, the flowers can be white, pink, peach or red, flowering through summer and into autumn.Wersquore particularly fond of this relatively small and compact iegated shrub because of its hardiness and versatility.With striking green and white foliage throughout the year, it can create an attractive centrepiece in a pot, form a focal point in a border or grow into an unusual hedge ndash it will even climbgrown against a wall.Although lsquoEmerald Gaietyrsquo is one of our best-sellers, therersquos a wide range of other Euonymus ieties, offering a choice of size and leaf colour.Euonymus do produce flowers, but they are small and somewhat insignicant, and this shrub is primarily grown for its eye-catching, all-year-round foliage.This is one of the hardiest evergreen shrubs available, with flat, glossy, leaves ending in spines ndash somewhat like holly.Very successful in East Lothian, itrsquos tolerant of low light levels and can survive even in shady corners of the garden.It is particularly attractive in autumn winter, producing long racemes of yellow flowers which turn into blue black berries after flowering.Although the ultimate height of this shrub will y depending on its situation,unchecked and in ideal conditions it can eventually reach up to .- metres tall with a spread in the range of .-. metres wide. However, in our local conditions wersquove rarely seen it much above -.metres.If yoursquore looking for an evergreen tree, itrsquos worth remembering many coners are extremely hardy and tolerant of adverse conditions, surviving in severe coastal conditions and at altitude.The tree wersquore highlighting is the Picea omorika, sometimes called the Serbian or Bosnian spruce, being native to those countries.With dense, short green needles that are slightly whitish underneath, it has a dense, columnar habit, and forms a graceful, slender, conical feature in the garden.It is extremely hardy and, although it doesnrsquot require any pruning, it can be trimmed to remain in proportion to the garden.Many of our customers love garden lighting, and the stable conical form of P omorika makes it the ideal plant for strings of lights!For something a little dferent, why not try Phormium Phormium is sometimes known as the New Zealand flax because of its country of origin. It is one of the hardiest plants we know and indeed is used effectively at the front of the garden centre as a windbreak!Grown primarily for its form, the clumps of strap-like leaves are virtually indestructible, and some years will even produce tall, architectural flowering spikes which dry and remain a feature.Most often grown as a focal point, it can also be used to create an unusual hedge.There are many ieties of Phormium to choose from offering a wide range of colours, from eye-catching yellow through to deep, purplish-black, or combinations of colours on striped leaves.Similarly, therersquos a great selection of sizes available, from small compact ieties to the larger ieties that can exceed two metres.Itrsquos been very dficult to choose only five of our favourite evergreens, because there are so many wonderful plants that will provide you with structure, form, colour and interest throughout the year.If you require advice on these plants or other options, just please speak to one of our plant team and theyrsquoll help you choose an evergreen plant thatrsquos just right for you!

title: coronavirus-scotland-book-covid-test-testing-centres
story: The First Minister suggests some Scots have had trouble trying to book coronavirus tests over the weekend due to a "major spike" in demand, which resulted in technical issues.Butyou are experiencing symptoms, how do you get a test  Heres everything you need to know.If you think you are experiencing symptoms of coronavirus, you should take a test. A test should be taken within the first three days of showing symptoms, but testing is effective until day five.You wonrsquot normally be tested after day  unless itrsquos for a specic reason. This will be agreed on a case-by-case basis.Anyone with symptoms of coronavirus should be tested. You can book a test for either yourself,someone you care for ora child in your care.Key workers, and anyone in their household with symptoms, can access testing through their employer in the first instance and will be given priority.For more information on key worker priority, visit NHS Inform.Currently, there are testing sites at Glasgow, Edinburgh, Aberdeen and Prestwick airports, and in Perth and Inverness at the University of the Highlands and Islands campuses.There are also home testing kits available, which are delivered and collected by Amazon and Royal Mail. You can order one here.There are several ways to get tested for Covid- in Scotland.You can have a home testing kit delivered to your home, or attend one of the testing sites.To book a test, you are asked to complete a self-help guide, which can be found online, to checkyou are eligible. If you cant access the form online, you can callthe coronavirus helpline on   .The coronavirus tests involves taking a swab of the inside of your nose and the back of your throat. This is done using a long cotton bud.According to NHS Inform, results are issued to whoever booked the test and are fed back into public health records.They are sent by text to your mobile phone and should be with you within  hours.

title: hollies-day-centre-musselburgh-reopen-monday
story: Liz Shannon, manager, said the reopening of the High Street facility, which offers activities for older people as well as a public cafe, would be ldquoin a limited capacity to allow for social distancing.The public cafe and hairdresser will be back in business on Monday, with hopes that other activities, such as the lunch club, might start again next month.Ms Shannon said: ldquoMajor work has been carried out over the lockdown period, including a deep clean of the building.ldquoWe are sorry but, due to the current pandemic, a number of changes have had to be put in place for customersrsquo and staff safety, and to comply with Government health and safety guidelines. As before, we are a cash-only facility.The cafe will reopen in the hall am-pm, Monday to Wednesday.Ms Shannon said: ldquoWe will see how it will work and,it works well, we can extend our days back to five.ldquoThere will be a limited number of customers able to attend, around , and the time in the cafe limited to  minutes per person. Entry will be by the black gate from High Street into the hall. A track and trace system will be in place and customers will be required to leave their name and contact telephone number, have their hands sanitised and wear a face covering until seated. All must comply with these conditions or entry will be prohibited. A limited menu will be provided at this stage.The hairdresser at the day centre will also reopen by appointment, following the same days, times and entry system.Ms Shannon said: ldquoCustomers for the hairdresser will have to keep a mask on at all times and use the stair lt to the first floor. They will be required to bring their own refreshments as no tea or coffee will be provided.She stressed both cafe and hairdresser customers would leave from the front door of the building.Ms Shannon paid tribute to Musselburgh-based RR Roofing  Building Ltd, which came to the rescue last week to carry out repairs on a leaky roof at the centre which, it had been feared, could have been a major setback to the reopening.

title: parents-urged-keep-cars-away-entrance-wallyford-primary-school
story: The appeal was made after a lot more families used vehicles one day recently because of heavy rain.The school said no one should drive up to the building on Futures Way to park on roads beside the school gates or park across pavements.Banners and lamppost notices have been put outside all schools by East Lothian Council asking families for their support amidst the Covid- crisis.A council spokesperson said: ldquoWersquore asking all our school communities to avoid taking cars to school and to walk for some or all of their journey regardless of the weather. This improves road safety, reduces pollution and creates space around our schools, which is especially important when we need to observe physical distancing.ldquoWallyford Primary School has a very supportive parent community and we all hope that the families will take on board this advice, which will keep their children safe.

title: 60-events-offer-east-lothian-online-heritage-festival
story: East Lothian Online Heritage Festival boasts events ranging from virtual guided tours and presentations to films and workshops.The festival, on until September , is running in place of the traditional Archaeology and Local History Fortnight, which has been postponed.Events include The Big Glassworks Dig at Port Seton on September  and . Digs will be broadcast live so everyone can follow any discoveries from the old glassworks as they are uncovered.Battlefield events commemorating the Battles of Dunbar, Pinkie Cleugh and Prestonpans, including live footage from the commemoration ceremonies, will take place, as well as online exhibitions and films related to the Year of Coast and Waters, using historic images and oral histories from the archives.Councillor Norman Hampshire, cabinet spokesman for the environment, said: ldquoIrsquom delighted our archaeology service has developed this alternative way of celebrating East Lothianrsquos rich heritage and history.ldquoWith a vast array of historic buildings and sites to explore virtually through more than  events, Irsquod encourage people to participate.On Saturday, events include the chance to join the Salt of the Earth project for a day of celebration of the heritage of the Prestonpans, Cockenzie and Port Seton, Longniddry and Gosford areas.There is the chance to take a virtual walk around Tranentrsquos historic burgh boundary and a guided heritage walk over, under and around seven bridges over the Esk in Musselburgh.Also on Saturday, Graeme Cavers, from AOC Archaeology, will give a presentation about how LiDAR was used to map the archaeology of the Lammermuirs. A traditional skills festival looking at everything from stone carving and pottery to herb foraging and plaster casting takes place.A short film based on interviews with fishermen from Cockenzie and Port Seton will be shown, while there is also a chance to find out how to build your own lsquoTrace Italiennersquo fort.On Sunday, Nicola Wright will tell stories inspired by coast, water and archaeology, while a childrenrsquos workshop takes place in Amisfield Walled Garden, near Haddington. Liz Curtis shares stories behind the place names of East Lothian and there is a presentation about John Muirrsquos home in Dunbar.Monday starts with a look at the history of Dunbar, which is marking  years since the town was granted its charter.Gullane and Dirleton History Society hosts a virtual guided walk of the Gullane end of the old branch railway line.The following day, a film looking at the Cousland Smiddy is shown, while there is a slideshow of some of the historic re-enactment events that Catching the Past has been involved in.Historian David Affleck explores the history of Whittingehame Estate, while Kate Campbell has written a collection of poetry inspired by the area around Whiteadder Reservoir.On Wednesday, a short slideshow looks at the history of county ports and harbours and Courier columnist Tim Porteus tells three East Lothian tales.For more information, go to johngraycentre.org

title: first-full-east-lothian-council-meeting-since-lockdown-sees-local-heroes-praised
story: A momentrsquos silence was held for those people who died from Covid- and their families, as councillors paid tribute to the community efforts which had come to the fore during the crisis.Councillor Fiona Dugdale summed up the praise from elected members during the virtual meeting, held online, by saying: ldquoI do not think there are enough words to thank our staff and the amazing army of volunteers who stepped up in the midst of a national health crisis not knowing how it would affect or its impact on their own families.ldquoThe depth of gratitude is immense to all our staff and all our volunteers across the county,ldquoThey are all our local heroes at the heart of our communities.And Provost John McMillan told the committee: ldquoA hero is an ordinary person who does extraordinary things and all those ordinary people who stepped up did extraordinary things.The council meeting heard that a snapshot of services provided by the council and its partners the week before community resilience teams stood down showed , people who were shielding were in contact with support teams and , free school meals and lunch packs were delivered to children.The six childrenrsquos hubs which provided care for the families of key workers and vulnerable children at its peak in June saw  young people attend and  teaching staff working in them.Councillor Willie Innes, council leader, said: ldquoRight across the county, people have been magnicent.ldquoI am proud of our council staff, who have worked above and beyond to ensure the safety and wellbeing of communities.And Councillor Jim Goodfellow, spokesperson for community wellbeing, said: ldquoThe magnicent numbers of volunteers who have come forward has demonstrated what this county is all about.Councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell also added her thanks to staff and volunteers, pointing to work in her Preston SetonGosford ward, from community councils to third sector and volunteers.And fellow ward councillor Lachlan Bruce said that too many people to name had made remarkable efforts to support the communities.Mr Bruce said: ldquoWe are incredibly lucky in this county and it has highlighted how great this county is, with communities coming together, all doing amazing work.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, education spokesperson, passed on her thanks to parents and carers for their work.And Councillor Craig Hoy also paid tribute to shop workers who kept services open.He said: ldquoLocal shops, petrol stations and small businesses, as well as large supermarkets and small stores, all stayed open to support their communities throughout and should be thanked.Councillor Stuart Currie called for a moment of silence to be held, saying: ldquoIt is right to remember the people who are not going to see the other side of this pandemic and their families.The council closed the meeting with a moment of silent reflection in tribute.

title: fresh-hot-tub-suite-plans-dunbars-bayswell-park-hotel
story: Ambitious proposals for Dunbarrsquos Bayswell Park Hotel were sent to East Lothian Council at the beginning of last month.At that time, the plans included not only an annexe building, between the hotel and the clfs to the north, but also changes within the established hotel.However, that planning application has now been withdrawn.A spokesman for Fitzgerald and Associates Ltd, which represents the Bayswell Park Hotel, stressed that the plans were not dead.Instead, they will be split into two separate applications ndash one focusing on changes to the existing hotel and the other at the proposed annexe.Plans for the main hotel building were expected to be lodged with the councilrsquos planning department this week, with the annexe proposals expected next month.According to the proposals, about pound, would be invested in the business, which would ldquosecure the future of the hotel.A supporting statement said: ldquoThe development proposals will address weaknesses, strengthen the enterprise, promote higher occupancy levels, deliver a much-improved standard of service that will attract customers and, most importantly, facilitate the delivery of a top-quality hotel.Changes in the hotel, which dates back more than  years, would see four single rooms altered to create two double twin rooms. On the ground floor, a new dining area would be created through a -cover restaurant and improved lounge bar, with a conservatory being removed.The planning statement, included in the now-withdrawn application, states: ldquoThe present areas are too small, and the new restaurant and lounge bar will provide a spacious attractive welcoming ambiance. The comfortable, high-quality dining and relaxation space will be available for both resident guests and for non-resident clients.Concerns had been raised at the townrsquos community council meeting about the proposed annexe, which would offer impressive views out to sea. The design showed a three-storey building, with three suites on each floor.Jacquie Bell, secretary of the community council, highlighted there were a number of neighbours voicing concerns about the proposals on social media.Fears included the suitability of the design of the building, while others were worried about building on that area of the land.However, there were members of the community council who were keen to find out more about the scheme.Craig Rapson said: ldquoThere is a need for hotel accommodation in Dunbar.ldquoComments about safety issues ndash they are not going to build somethingit is not safe.

title: haddington-residents-yard-sale-helps-support-community-kitchen
story: Residents of Burnside, Clerkington Road and Fairway came together to do their bit for Our Community Kitchen.The lsquoyard salersquo collected pound for the group, which meets in Haddington Bowling Club.Elaine Gale, who founded Our Community Kitchen, was delighted with the success of the event at the beginning of the month.She said: ldquoIt is just so lovely.ldquo[Support from the community] has been enormous really and the amount and sheer scale of support we have had locally for what we are doing is absolutely incredible.The money raised will go towards the general running costs of the group, which, pre-coronavirus, was serving up lunches to people who were suffering from isolation in the bowling club.However, with social gatherings ruled out, the group decided to continue preparing meals but instead take them to peoplersquos homes.Meals such as chicken and leek pie and stovies have been delivered to homes throughout Haddington during the lockdown period.That will be scaled back slightly as restrictions are eased but Elaine said they were still delivering more than  meals a week to people in need.Volunteers have also been taking the time to phone vulnerable members of the community to check they are alright.The scheme will continue and Elaine said: ldquoAs a charity, we are committed to looking after the community.ldquoThat is part of what we will be doing going forward thatrsquos not going to stop.ldquoWe recognise people will still need us.

title: pop-up-park-created-beside-dunbar-leisure-pool
story: Funding has been secured through the Spaces for People programme to create a small park on the grass area between the pool and Lauderdale House.George Robertson, from the townrsquos community council, outlined the plans for the site. On Monday morning, he said: ldquoThis provides an area adjacent to High Street where people can enjoy their takeaway meals, ice creams, etc in a safe environment with social distancing.ldquoThe benches were installed this morning by the East Lothian Council amenities team.ldquoViridor were kind enough to provide additional recycling bins and we hope that people will make good use of these for the disposal of waste.ldquoThe area is marked by sail flags which are visible from High Street.

title: lyn-jardine-hopes-snps-east-lothian-candidate-scottish-parliament-election-2021
story: Lyn Jardine, a former chair of Womenrsquos Aid East and Midlothian, has joined Dunbar and East Linton Councillor Paul McLennan, and Iain Whyte, office manager for Paul Wheelhouse, South of Scotland MSP and energy minister, in seeking to be the partyrsquos candidate for East Lothian in .The party is expected to announce its candidate in late October, with hopefuls vetted before local members are asked to choose their preferred person.Mrs Jardine said: ldquoIn order to deliver both independence and the support we deserve, East Lothian needs an MSP who exhibits the competence and determination to bring about the changes necessary.ldquoIrsquove shown that competence ndash serving our communities in both professional and voluntary capacity ndash and Irsquom determined to keep doing so as your MSP.ldquoIrsquove worked all my le in housing, health and social care, across public and third sectors, as well as self-employed.ldquoI served several years as chair of Womenrsquos Aid East and Midlothian and on both the child and adult protection committees across both local authorities.A new MSP for East Lothian will be selected when the elections take place in May.Iain Grayhas held the seat since  but is not seeking re-election.Labour are yet to announce their candidate, with Councillor Craig Hoy, who represents the Haddington and Lammermuir ward on East Lothian Council, already named as the Conservativesrsquo candidate.No other candidate has yet been announced.Mrs Jardine, who lives in Whittingehame, felt the SNP was ldquoin a good place across the county.The elected organiser for East Lothian SNP, who would be the partyrsquos first woman candidate for East Lothian for the Scottish Parliament, said: ldquoI worked with the campaign team supporting the successful European and Westminster election campaigns, and I have no doubt that whoever is selected, our members will put the same passion into campaigning for a better deal for East Lothian and a fairer, more equal Scotland.

title: east-lothian-council-astro-turf-ban
story: The schoolrsquos popular astroturf pitch ndash used primarily for hockey but also other activities ndash proved too big a draw for youngsters as classes ed full-time and it was closed to students at breaks and lunchtime.Parents urged the school to reconsider the decision after youngsters came home claiming they had been told the risk of them touching goal posts ndash and potentially creating a higher risk of spreading Covid- ndash was too great.And the school said that it would introduce a system which would allow children access to the pitch one day a week on a year by year basis.As classes ed in full last Monday, it is understood staff became concerned at the number of students gathering together on the astroturf pitch from dferent years.However, the decision to ban children from the pitch left some parents bemused.One mum took to social media, saying: ldquoSurely the kids can touch door frames and bins and walls in all the other outdoor areas ndash why are the goal posts so scary Another added: ldquoI understand they are under pressure and trying to keep kids and adults safe but surely this isnrsquot necessary One mum received a reply from the schoolrsquos PE department pledging to look into a way more supervision could be given to the pitch to allow youngsters to use it in a ldquosafe and sensible manner.Each year group has now been allowed to use the astroturf one day a week.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoThe astroturf is a popular facility at North Berwick High School.ldquoIn line with official guidance, the school is discouraging large groups from congregating and the space was being used by a number of dferent year groups at the same time.ldquoIt was closed to young people for two days to allow the staff team to put in place a schedule that will allow each year group to use it one day a week with staff supervision and cleaning in place.ldquoThis is especially important as it is also used for PE. North Berwick High School, like all our schools, is working hard to understand and apply guidance on theto our buildings.ldquoWhere we can identy better ways of working we are doing so. This is one example.

title: preston-lodge-high-school-headteacher-gavin-clark-apologises-pupils-soaked
story: Initial guidelines introduced by the school meant pupils were told to go outside at lunchtime and during breaks despite the downpours, with claims they were only allowed inside to use the toilets. Some pupils said they ed home wearing jackets and hoodies still soaked from being out in the rain earlier in the day.Afterwards, Mr Clark sent a letter to families, telling them: ldquoWe very much regret the fact that many of our students got wet at break, lunch and or in PE lessons on Monday and we have worked hard over the last  hours to reassure a number of parents carers who raised understandable concerns.ldquoWe were perhaps working too hard to meet national guidance, and on this occasion our desire to maximise student time outside and prevent large gatherings of students indoors, as per Government advice, negatively impacted on student wellbeing.And in the schoolrsquos PLus newsletter, he said: ldquoWe have had a really good week at Preston Lodge, after a dficult Monday. Heavy rain, combined with a challenging set of Government guidelines, led to many students getting wet on that day, but I am glad to say that today our new approach to indoor breaks worked well and, other than those who chose to go outside, everyone stayed dry!An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoAll schools are working hard to implement guidance to provide a safeto buildings. In particular, secondary schools have to minimise large gatherings within indoor spaces and encourage small groups with physical distancing outwith.ldquoOur schools have been clear to all parents that children and young people should come to school dressed for the weather.ldquoTheto school this year has been challenging and we, and our schools, are working hard to understand and apply guidance. Where we can identy better ways of working we are doing so. The headteacherrsquos letter was part of this process.

title: tranent-parish-churchs-minister-leaving-new-role-hospice
story: The Rev Erica Wishart will host her last service at Tranent Parish Church on Sunday before taking on a new role as a trainee specialist palliative care chaplain, working for St Andrewrsquos Hospice in Airdrie.The -year-old told the Courier it would be ldquoa wrench to leave the Tranent congregation.She said: ldquoI feel privileged to have been able to spend the last five-and-a-half years serving the people of Tranent and Elphinstone.ldquoFrom my first day here, they made me feel so welcome and very much part of the community.ldquoThe folk here are straight-talking and kind-hearted and, in my book, thatrsquos a winning combination!ldquoTo me, the church should always be at the heart of the community, to help and support wherever there is a need and to lead the way at times of reflection such as Remembrance and Lent, as well as at happy times like Christmas and Easter.Last year, the minister, who is a mum-of-three and grandmother-of-five, was thrilled to be invited to the royal garden party in Edinburgh after being nominated by Michael Williams, Lord Lieutenant of East Lothian.The royal family hosts four garden parties a year ndash three at Buckingham Palace and one at the Palace of Holyroodhouse ndash with more than , people attending in total.They are designed to recognise and reward the public service of the attendees.Ahead of her move, Erica did not rule out ato East Lothian ndash where husband Bill is chaplain at Tranent Juniors ndash in the future.She said: ldquoThe congregation at Tranent Parish Church are a friendly, caring community of faith and they have taken not only me but also my husband Bill, our children and grandchildren into their hearts and we will miss them sorely ndash although wersquore only moving to my home townso Irsquom sure wersquoll stay in touch.ldquoBill and I love East Lothian and hope to retire somewhere near the coast in the future.ldquoWersquore so thankful for all the great experiences wersquove had while living in Tranent and the friends wersquove made we will keep them in our hearts and prayers when we go.Members of the congregation ed to the church for a service for the first time since March last Wednesday.However, social distancing and coronavirus-related restrictions mean that only a certain number of people will be allowed in the building for the ministerrsquos farewell service.She said: ldquoWhen things have settled down and back to some sort of normality, there will be some kind of big shindig.ldquoHopefully that can happen but it is definitely going to be emotional on Sunday.A successor is yet to be appointed as the Church of Scotland goes through the appropriate process.David Forrest, chairman of Tranentrsquos community council, wished Erica well in her new role.He said: ldquoShe will be much missed. She got on very well with the community council and was always willing to help. I cannot say a bad word about her.

title: 12-year-old-swims-length-english-channel-prestonpans-pool
story: Emily Bain, , from Prestonpans, swam  miles ndash the equivalent of crossing the English Channel ndash in her familyrsquos outdoor pool.A member of Tranent Amateur Swimming Club, she estimated she took  minutes per mile ndash and then swam a mile every day for three weeks to raise money for the British Heart Foundation .Emily had set herself the challenge as a tribute to her -year-old grandfather, George Shiells, who suffered from idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and died after having a heart attack in June.He and his we Linda had lived with Emily and her family on Doctor Gracie Drive for the last five years.Emily said: ldquoI wanted to do something for my papa and I love swimming so thought this would be a good way of doing it.ldquoOur pool is a bit like a giant paddling pool so I couldnrsquot do s in it. Instead, we put a rope around my waist and tied it to the garden fence, so it was like I was swimming on the spot ndash or sometimes I swam in circles around the pool for  minutes. It was quite hard but Irsquom so glad I did it.Emily, a pupil at Preston Lodge High School, has now raised pound, for BHFrsquos research into heart and circulatory diseases.Her mum Gaynor said: ldquoWe are so very, very proud of Emily not only because she wanted to do something in memory of her papa but of the hard work and dedication that she has shown in completing what was a very dficult challenge.ldquoShe was really close to my father and this was her way of paying tribute to him.ldquoWe are delighted that she has raised so much for the BHF and want to say a huge thank you to everyone who sponsored her. We are so grateful to them all.Emilyrsquos fundraising efforts come at a time when the BHF says it needs the publicrsquos support more than ever, describing the Covid- pandemic as the biggest challenge the charity has faced in its -year history. The temporary closure of its  shops across the UK, including  in Scotland, and the cancellation of fundraising events have had a devastating impact on income and, as a result, the BHFrsquos budget for investing in new research into heart and circulatory diseases will halve this year.James Jopling, head of BHF Scotland, said: ldquoWe are so grateful to Emily for her fantastic efforts and for coming up with such a brilliant idea to help us.ldquoOver the last few months, it has been truly inspiring to see our volunteers and fundraisers continuing to rise to the challenge, even at this extraordinary time, finding new ways to support us.ldquoThe coronavirus crisis will unfortunately have a long-lasting and devastating impact on charities like ours, with our funding for new research falling by up to poundm this year alone.ldquoThatrsquos why, not only do we need urgent help from our wonderful supporters, wersquore also urging the UK Government to ensure funding for vital research charities.ldquoFor us, it will mean we can protect the progress we have made so far and continue to transform the lives of those living with heart and circulatory diseases.For more about the work of the BHF and how to help support it, visit bhf.org.uk

title: dunbar-road-closure-one-way-street-plans-shelved
story: Hospital Road and Back Road were part of East Lothian Councilrsquos Spaces for People scheme to make temporary changes while coming out of lockdown.Proposals were drawn up for towns across the county to create physical distancing in streets and to support an expected increase in walking and cycling.Among the plans for Dunbar was to shut Hospital Road from the traffic lights on the northern side of the railway line to Kennelbrae to the south.Meanwhile, Back Road was to become one-way, with traffic heading uphill from Belhaven to the entrance to Winterfield Golf Club.Neither plan will now go ahead and a spokeswoman for the local authority told the Courier: ldquoBack Road and Hospital Road were put forward in our initial request for ideas from the public.ldquoThis was at a time when people were restricted from travelling more than five miles from their homes ndash there were greater numbers of people taking exercise locally, and fewer cars.ldquoFurther community feedback in the current climate has suggested that these moves are not presently required and so they are not being immediately progressed.ldquoWe continue to keep plans up to date and invite comments on our maps at www.eastlothian.gov.uk spacesforpeopleMembers of Dunbar Community Council were among those raising concerns about the proposals.Pippa Swan, the grouprsquos chairwoman, said discussions around the future of Back Road had been ongoing for a considerable period of time.She said: ldquoWe donrsquot have an opposition to a protected pedestrian route per se.ldquoWhat we are frustrated by is the area partnership raised this matter three years ago or more.ldquoThe council paid Peter Brett Associates to carry out a public consultation.ldquoA report has been prepared and it has been with the council for two years.ldquoWe have asked repeatedly to see the findings of that report but they have never appeared.ldquoWhat we were anxious about was whether something was going to be dumped on us that had no joined-up thinking and did not reflect the findings of the Peter Brett report.Mrs Swan stressed that the community council was keen to support improved cycle paths and footpaths, particularly for youngsters to get to school.However, she was concerned that closing Hospital Road would have a knock-on effect on the neighbouring streets.She added: ldquoWe want to be involved with discussions and understand what the outcomes of the discussions are.

title: dunbar-womans-long-distance-cycle-help-school-malawi
story: Harriet Woodward, Hannah McVicar and Anique Burke demonstrated immense pedal power, cycling from Birmingham to Edinburgh in a week.The trio had all visited the country, in southern Africa, and got on their bikes to help Jacaranda Primary and Secondary School.Anique, , from Dunbar, said: ldquoWe are definitely not keen cyclists.ldquoI had not cycled since I had a paper round when I was .ldquoWe did about  miles a day but sometimes we did more and sometimes less.ldquoOn the first day, we had six punctures but it was better after that.ldquoWe were camping most nights and we took all the stuff with us.ldquoWe would set off at am and some nights we would be finished by pmwe had a good day and others it was pm or pm.Each of the cycling fundraisers was donated a bike for the journey.The journey was supposed to take Anique, Harriet, of Birmingham, and Hannah, of Roslin, six days.However, the loss of a wheel just outside Berwick-upon-Tweed meant an extra day, with the trio reaching the finish line of Scotlandrsquos Capital on July .Anique, who also volunteered for the NHS at the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh in the Covid- ward, spent  months in Malawi after leaving Dunbar Grammar School in August .During her time in the country, she worked alongside youngsters at Yamikani House orphanage.She told the Courier that schools in Malawi were ldquocompletely dferent from those in Scotland.Leaving school without English would make it very dficult for anyone to find a job.According to the fundraising page set up ahead of the cycle: ldquoJacaranda is an incredible school that gives many great opportunities to children in the community and supports the childrenrsquos dreams.ldquoHowever, due to Covid- and the loss of jobs, many families in Malawi are struggling to feed themselves and the children are unable to attend school.It has been a busy summer for Anique, who worked alongside her mum, fashion designer Jacqui Burke, to help raise money for the good cause.Anique said: ldquoWhen I came home I started to make masks with my mum at the fashion school.ldquoWe raised just under pound, through making masks and asking for donations.ldquoWe made over  masks and gave them to the foodbank as well.The masks were made from the fabric she used to carry the babies and young children from the orphanage on her back while in Malawi.It was after the mask-making exploits that Anique was askedshe would take part in the -mile cycle.The medicine student at the University of Edinburgh said Malawi had made a sizeable impact on her le.She said: ldquoI donrsquot knowfun is the right word but it was a very memorable experience for all three of us.To support the good cause, go to gofundme f cycle-from-england-to-scotland

title: win-performance-haddington-pipe-band-shopping-locally
story: Haddington Pipe Band has launched a lsquoshop localrsquo scheme with a big prize on offer ndash a personal performance by the band for the lucky winner.The scheme has been devised as a thank you from the band to the many shops, cafes and other traders who have supported them over many years.Working alongside Haddington Business Community Partnershipand Haddington Farmersrsquo Market, pipe band members are encouraging people to spend their money in Haddington.The Courier is delighted to help promote such initiatives as part of our Love Local Business campaign.Ian Sutherland, band chairman, said: ldquoWe are indebted to so many wonderful shops, cafes, stallholders at the farmersrsquo market, and other businesses in the town and the wider area and at this dficult time for them, we thought we would try to give something back.ldquoThis lsquoshop localrsquo initiative is the result.Visitors to the town centre are being asked to pick up a card at the participating outlets, all of which will have a poster on display.Customers can then spend pound or more in six dferent shops which are involved in the project, with the card signed by the shopkeeper.When the shopper has six signatures, the card can be put in the prize box at the John Gray Centre.The closing date for submitting cards is September , with Provost John McMillan drawing the winner the following week.The winner will then be notied and arrangements made for the band to come together for a special performance.Among the businesses taking part are Gibsons, Graham the Jeweller, Ericarsquos, Oxfam, TV  Audio Repair Centre, Celebrations, Mains, The Loft, Fabrication, The Cheese Lady, Joe Forte Sports, Market Street Pharmacy, Naked Lunch and The Reading Room.Haddington Farmersrsquo Market is also taking part in the scheme, which was backed by Val Shields, chair of the market.Stallholders taking part in the scheme are Ballencrieff Pork, Belhaven Smokehouse, Falko, Fidra Gin, Letham Plants, Mungoswells Flour, Myco Bee Mushrooms, Phantassie Organics, Saltpigs Sea Salt, The Spice Witch and Winton Brewery.Mrs Shields said: ldquoHaddington Farmersrsquo Market is delighted to support this initiative from Haddington Pipe Band.ldquoAnything that encourages people to shop locally and support local businesses is to be applauded.ldquoWe have missed the pipe band entertaining us each month at the market and this is a kind gesture from them to support the local community during this pandemic.ldquoWe have calculated thateveryone in East Lothian spent an extra pound per week in local shops and businesses, that would be an extra pound.m per annum going back into our local communities. This means real jobs, better facilities and better places to live.Mr McMillan, who lives in the town and represents it on East Lothian Council, was hopeful that the initiative would encourage people to shop locally.He said: ldquoHaddington Pipe Band has always described itself as a lsquocommunity bandrsquo and it is truly living up to its values by doing this for the town.ldquoWith traders having kept going during the lockdown and now opening up to a new normal, the band has responded to all the support they have been given in the past, and I very much hope that this scheme will encourage folk to lsquosupport localrsquo.ldquoThe prize of a special pipe band performance is a unique idea, and I am sure it will help to drum up business for the town.Any other shops wishing to join the scheme are asked to call Alastair Bruce on  .

title: resilient-musselburgh-stands-months-helping-community
story: The team has been running a local emergency service since the last week in March, initially from a base at Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School before moving to Musselburgh East Community Learning Centre on Haddington Road.The efforts, which attracted about  local volunteers, were coordinated by Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council, Musselburgh Area Partnership and East Lothian Council workers.Help from the community council was given by chairperson Irene Tait, vice-chairperson Bernard Harkins and secretary Margaret Stewart.Also giving support were area partnership chairman Iain Clark and manager Stuart Baxter, as well as Jane Cummings, Pamela Martin, Donna Doherty and Trisha McGeachy from East Lothian Council.With help from the volunteers, aid was delivered to vulnerable people in the community during the Covid- crisis.Mrs Tait said: ldquoWith the help of volunteers, we have delivered hundreds of hot meals, soup and sandwiches, food parcels, hygiene products, prescriptions, activity packs for children and adults, newspapers, garden tools and much more. None of this would have been possible without our wonderful volunteers, who went above and beyond many times, so a huge thank you to them.ldquoWe would also like to thank Tesco, Hickory, Mercat Bar  Grill at Whitecraig, Pinkie Farm Shop and many of the local shops that donated to us during this time.ldquoThanks also to local organisations for their donations and help given to Resilient Musselburgh.ldquoLastly, our thanks go out to our community for continuing to do the right thing.

title: coronavirus-nearly-100-pupils-staff-self-isolating-across-lothians
story: Eighty-eight pupils and eight members of staff who have been in close and sustained contact with the pupils who tested positive have been told to self-isolate for  days as a precautionary measure.Currently, there is no evidence of transmission within the schools themselves.On Wednesday, East Lothian Council said it was ldquoa worrying time for families after it was confirmed a pupil had tested positive.Details of the age of the pupil or what class they are in at the Prestonpans primary school have not been released.A spokesman for the local authority said: ldquoThatrsquos why we are working with NHS Lothianrsquos health protection team and will continue to closely monitor the situation and follow all national guidance and the health advice provided.ldquoChildren who have been in direct contact with the confirmed case have been contacted and will be staying at home for  days.ldquoThe school remains open, in line with expert public health advice."The Health Protection Team in NHS Lothian has worked with single cases in six schools across Lothianrsquos four separate local authority areas to contact trace and assess the safety measures in place, such as social distancing and enhanced cleaning.Preston Tower is the only school in East Lothian to have recorded a positive test.All of the schools in East Lothian, Edinburgh, Midlothian and West Lothian remain open following the inidual cases and parents have been told that their child should still attend, unless instructed otherwise.Professor Alison McCallum, director of public health and health policy, said: ldquoWe have been made aware of a number of pupils who have tested positive for Covid- over the course of this week.ldquoWe know this is a worrying time for them and their families, but indeed also for other people in the local school community.ldquoOur teams are working with schools to ensure that all of the necessary infection control measures are in place to protect other young people and their families.ldquoAll of the schools remain open and parents should continue to send their children to school.

title: east-lothian-pupils-asked-bring-face-masks-school-monday
story: Lesley Brown, the councilrsquos head of education and childrenrsquos services, said in the letter: ldquoAs yoursquoll be aware, the Scottish Government has announced that, from August , face coverings should be worn by young people attending secondary schools when they are moving around the school in corridors and confined communal areaswhere physical distancing is particularly dficult to maintain.ldquoThis new advice comes from the World Health Organisationand is based on evidence that transmission risks amongst teenagers are the same as amongst adults.ldquoThese measures will ensure we are up-to-date with the latest advice about how to keep our schools open and safe.ldquoBy following these new guidelines, you and your child will be supporting our schools to ensure health and safety remains a key priority, and that all staff and pupils can be confident they are in a safe environment.ldquoThis means that, from Monday, you should provide your child with a face covering to wear at school in these circumstances.Students may also wear face coverings in classrooms, though this is not compulsory.Face coverings must be worn by adults in classrooms where they cannot keep a two-metre distance and are interacting face-to-face with other adults and or children and young people for  minutes or more.Those who have a health condition or disability which affects their ability to wear a face covering hygienically or safely are exempt from the ruling.Schools will also continue to reinforce the importance of high standards of cleaning, personal hand and respiratory hygiene, and physical distancing.

title: swimmers-given-medical-treatment-washed-rocks
story: The townrsquos coastguard and RNLI crews, alongside an RNLI crew from Dunbar, received a call to go to North Berwickrsquos East Beach at about pm after reports of two people in the water.A spokesman for North Berwick Coastguard Rescue Team said: ldquoWe made contact with the first informant, who directed us to the exact location of the incident.ldquoBy the time we arrived on scene, the casualties had been helped out of the water by beach goers who then helped us recover the casualties back to the leboat station so they could be handed over to the Scottish Ambulance Service for treatment.ldquoRememberyou see someone or something you are concerned about on the shoreline, clf, mud or on the sea. Dial  and ask for the coastguard.A North Berwick RNLI statement said: ldquoOur volunteers launched but were stood down en-route as the casualties made it ashore with help from bystanders.ldquoThey were picked up by North Berwick Coastguard Rescue Team and transported to the station, where casualty care was carried out by our crew as they were in shock having swallowed water and been washed over rocks.ldquoThey were handed into the care of the Scottish Ambulance Service.ldquoThere were breaking waves on scene which may have looked small but can be powerful. Depending on the tide, rocks can be partially covered, which can be dangerous. Shortly after the call-out, a rip current was observed in the area, with some swimmers caught in it, though they were washed to shore by large waves.ldquoOur beaches are beautul but, in certain conditions, can be dangerousyou are unaware of the hazards, or donrsquot know how to keep yourself safe. As there are no leguards in our area, you should take particular caution.

title: funds-haddington-car-park-set-diverted-preston-tower
story: Councillors will be asked to approve proposals to shelve the Whittingehame Drive transport hub plans on Tuesday and ert the cash into helping restore Preston Tower and the doocot to inject new le into the centre of Prestonpans.A report to East Lothian Councilrsquos cabinet meeting reveals that despite an extension to the time given to use Scottish Government funding for the Haddington proposals, it was not going to be completed in time.And it asks councillors to agree to move the funding set aside for the project ndash up to pound, ndash to a new project.The Scottish Government funding for town centre projects has to be fully committedby the revised deadline of March next year and spent by next September.The transport hub plans for Haddington would have seen a new car park created on Whittingehame Drive, on the outskirts of the town centre, to encourage people to park and ride to the shops.However, it was met with a backlash from local businesses and shop owners, who feared the impact it would have on their customersthey were unable to park outside the shops.The report to cabinet says: ldquoThe grant criteria being extended was particularly welcomed however, with priorities completely realigned as a result of Covid-, the head of infrastructure has flagged that the Whittingehame Drive cannot be completed within the extended timeframe.ldquoThe project has also been the subject of signicant community representation and, alongside Town Centre Access Strategy work, wide-ranging speculation.Instead, it suggests the funding is moved to support work on restoring Preston Tower and the doocot in the town, which is already being done in association with the Scottish Historic Building Trust, National Trust for Scotland, Preston Seton GosfordArea Partnership, Prestonpans Community Council and the PSG Great Place Project.It says that work was also estimated to cost between pound, and pound, and would have a ldquopositive impact on the town, making the medieval attraction safe for visitors in the future.It also points out Prestonpans itself has lost out on funding in the past.It says: ldquoInvestment levels in Prestonpans have been lower than in other centres.ldquoThe inclusion of regeneration work on Preston Tower and the doocot together with the work on High Street in the context of the PSG Great Place project would see Prestonpans benefit signicantly from this grant award, providing opportunity to add and enhance attractions and public access to those attractions.ldquoThe principal aim of the project is to help reduce local inequalities and contribute to the regeneration of Prestonpans town centre in collaboration with the local community.Preston Tower dates back to the th century. The doocot on its land was built in the mid th century after Oliver Cromwell had sacked the tower, which has a pit-prison and stands four storeys high.

title: musselburgh-racecourse-keen-bring-back-spectators
story: The racecourse had hoped to open to the public this Sunday with the limited number of racegoers however did not get the go ahead from Scottish Government.The course said discussions were ongoing with the government and racing body Scottish Racing and as soon as approvals were given it would look to hold a pilot race day.Bill Farnsworth, racecourse general manager, said: ldquoWe have developed a robust plan for hosting  spectators in conditions where we maximise the benefits of having extensive outdoor areas which can safely maintain social distancing.ldquoScottish Rugby has hosted the first Scottish sporting event with spectators and we understand racing fans are keen to experience the same thrill of enjoying live sport. We are working hard with the Scottish Government and other relevant agencies to agree a plan which meets everyonersquos expectations.ldquoIt is important that we start the process of getting our race day staff back to work, not to mention supporting all our race day suppliers, ancillary staff, bookmakers and others whose livelihoods depend on the racing industry.Musselburgh will continue to race behind closed doors until all approvals are granted and has meetings scheduled for Sunday September , Saturday, September , and Sunday, September .
